Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: RUI: Collection Improvement of Marshall University's WV Vertebrate Survey Museum: West Virginia Natural History Updated and Online
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal's goal is to save West Virginia's primary natural history collection which includes over 21,000 mammals, amphibians, and reptiles amassed over 70 years. Almost every species that has been described in West Virginia is included, even federally endangered species. This collection is larger than in any other museum nationally and as so is a unique resource and should be developed for training the next generation of biologists who can then study, maintain, and protect Appalachia's animals. However, it is in urgent need of new equipment and curation to ensure its survival. Additionally, once the database is developed it will be possible to make this collection nationally/globally accessible via the Web.
Marshall University is a primarily undergraduate teaching institution in southwestern West Virginia. This collection has tremendous impact on its students and the local Appalachian community. It is used to train students in biology courses and students actively use the collections for research, presentations, and publications. The collections are also used for K-12 outreach focusing on local diversity and conservation ecology. Education outreach and early exposure to science is crucial for the development of a scientifically literate population in West Virginia, an educationally and socioeconomically challenged state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We worked to update and remodel the West Virginia Biological Survey Museum at Marshall University.  We have replaced the old metal shelving system by modernizing it with a mobile shelf system that increases the collection’s available space and optimizes specimen accessibility.  We have also installed new cabinetry fixtures that meet natural history collection guidelines for safe storage of specimens.  With these two installations, we have accomplished a more organized and more efficient means of locating and accessing each specimen in our collection.  We have also installed a new heating and cooling unit that is capable of maintaining a plus or minus five degrees from room temperature setting in the museum, for optimum storage conditions.  The previously existing workstation furniture has been replaced with new task-oriented desks and work areas.  This allows for more efficient use of the museum for both curation procedures and the study of each specimen. Also new paint and flooring were added to the room.

The WVBSM now has a digital presence, with the creation of a website that includes basic information on all the Mammals of West Virginia, Fun Facts, and color photographs.  The website introduces the WVBSM to the community and the world, and provides a unique opportunity for anyone to find out more about the mammals in the collection.

We have spent a lot of dealing with safety issues as there is arsenic in some of the mammal skins. The development of standard operation procedures for the arsenic contaminated collection has been finalized as is the procedures for storing these older specimens into the collection to minimize the spread of arsenic contamination into the new cabinets and display areas. The arsenic skins are also now separated from the rest of the collection to make it easy to keep students and visitors from handling these specimens.

We have also expanding our outreach program so that we have more opportunities to involve local schools and organizations. In the Museum Display and Outreach Development class (which was taught 3 times during the granting period) we have increased our displays – some for example include: an alligator display, tortoise display, skull morphology display, honeybee display, touchable fur display, snake display and a leg bone homology and a skull bone homology display (See some attached images). This has increased our overall visibility and our recognition in the school due to the ongoing building of the displays and our interactions with the student body. These displays are located at the already existing bison display and give us a huge opportunity for outreach not just in our own campus but bringing in grade schools and other youth based programs to see and interact with our touch friendly displays. Additionally during the times Dr. Strait taught her systematics class during this granting period, the student designed K-12 outreach kits for local schools/programs that can checked out through the museum.
